subject: Philosophy
title: The Liar Paradox
description: A tiny lesson with a big payoff: The Liar Paradox.

hook.text: 'This sentence is false.' If it's true, it's false. If it's false, it's true. Your brain just broke.

buildup.text: The liar paradox has stumped logicians since ancient Greece. It's a sentence that can't be true or false.

discovery.text: It reveals a crack in logic itself: self-referential statements can create irreconcilable contradictions.

twist.text: Kurt GÃ¶del used a version of this to prove that no logical system can be both complete and consistent.

climax.text: The liar paradox isn't a party trick. It's a deep result about the limits of formal reasoning.

punchline.text: Logic has limits. This sentence proves it.

quiz.question: Why is the liar paradox significant?
options: It shows that self-reference can break logical systems
